0 Param data.1 string m_text: I am a tool.
I had the great misfortune of being
born the princess of a small nation.
The people. Everything was for the people.
I heard that all the time as a child.
I never grew to resent the people.
But I knew what my parents meant when they spoke
those words: "It's all for us."
What kept that from truly corrupting me
was my love for one man.
He was the prince of a neighboring nation.
We understood each other, and fell deeply in love.
I had never been happier.
One day the prince of a large nation asked to marry me.
The news spread like wildfire.
Seeing my parents so happy disgusted me.
But I am thankful for that.
It only strengthened my resolve.
I took the hand of my beloved prince
and left everything I had ever known.
Though we felt we were living a dream,
it wasn't easy leaving our lives behind.
Nevertheless, we fled.
Farther. Always farther.
We were such fools.
Our short-lived freedom soon met its end.
We made a promise to one another as we faced our pursuers.
We would not fear death, even if it meant becoming Lost.
Somewhere, someday, we would be together forever.
Then we took our own lives.
I knew at once this was not the Living World,
and that I had become one of the Lost.
I was pleased to discover this,
as it was what we wanted.
But my love was nowhere to be found.
I wandered the Beyond in search of him.
The souls passing on to the next life gave light to this dark place.
Meanwhile, the other Lost I met along the way
seemed utterly consumed by their thoughts.
I feared but one thing:
the fate that awaits the Lost who fail to fulfill their desires.
Becoming one of the Fallen.
At that point, merely fading would have been a mercy.
But I did not wish to become a monster who
attacked the living and dead indiscriminately.
Each time I witnessed one of the Lost turn Fallen,
it tugged at the few heartstrings I had left.
I knew I didn't have long
once I felt my memories grow faint.
Who knows how long I'd been searching.
That was when I found him at last.
In that moment, it all became clear.
I knew why I'd failed to find him:
only I had died that day.
He was not yet prepared to die,
and so he clung to life instead.
He married another princess, was blessed with a child,
and lived happily ever after.
Visions of my parents floated before my eyes, taunting me.
All I ever wanted was love.
I wanted to BE loved.
I suddenly realized I was laughing uncontrollably.
I just want love...
However fleeting it may be.
My grandmother was a lovely woman.
She's the one who raised me.
She was humble; hardly said a word about herself.
Only once did I hear her speak ill of anyone: my parents,
who, in her defense, had abandoned me as a child.
I never forgot her Seven-Day Sending.
It awakened something in me that I lived by.
Life must be allowed to run its course.
That's what she spent her whole life
trying to teach me.
So, as thanks to her and this realm,
which cares so much for its dead,
I chose to devote my life to the kingdom.
I chose to join the Blood Guard.
The kingdom and its sovereign
held life above all else.
I was proud to be protecting the sovereign,
who taught me that a kingdom is its people.
I lived by those words, too.
They made me the devoted member of the Blood Guard that I was.
I was charged with protecting the heirs
the sovereign brought into the world.
It was an honor to protect her children,
and thus the future of the kingdom itself.
The boy grew especially attached to me.
I'd never felt such happiness before.
I couldn't help but think of him as family.
Until...
One day I received an order.
I was to be the one to kill him.
The kingdom had no need for the life I'd fought so hard to protect.
He could not be allowed to live.
The order was clearly insane,
but I was in no position to protest.
The decision had been made. He was to be sacrificed.
I couldn't understand why.
So I secreted him out of the realm in defiance.
I recalled my grandmother's teachings:
life must be allowed to run its course.
It was an awful decision.
Perhaps I put too much on his shoulders,
as my parents had done to me.
Time wasn't enough to wash away the regret,
which has been with me ever since.
The next time I saw him, he was a young man.
He had survived.
The boy had outrun his horrible fate.
And now he stood before me.
Fate was testing me. I could feel it.
I had no way to save him, nor even words to comfort him.
All I could do was meet his sword with mine.
And in the end, the life I'd failed to save took mine instead.
I burdened him with yet another crime.
Such is my legacy.
My soul has been overrun.
Overrun with disgust and sadness.
What should I have done?
I still don't know the answer.
But if nothing else,
should we ever meet again...
I will offer up my soul to him.
Why are our lives so much longer than the other tribes'?
Our ancestors must have wondered
the same thing, beginning the quest for knowledge
that took us to such heights.
We spent generations studying the precepts
of reincarnation, a pursuit that pushed us
to a higher level of being.
We became known as the Tribe of Life,
a nomadic people with nowhere to call home.
We roamed the realm, making a meager living
exchanging our knowledge of science and medicine for coin.
This sustained us for many, many years.
Looking back, selling our knowledge of science and medicine
was what led to our undoing.
Even then, I felt uneasy about the arrangement.
The sums they offered were too good to be true.
The largest nation in the world had requested our services,
an offer which clouded our judgment.
My own brother was among those dispatched
to work at their research facility.
And I, being both younger and inexperienced, was left behind.
Months passed, and our people did not return.
Their contracts ended, and still we heard nothing.
But this did not cause me worry.
I felt only...jealousy.
I was unable to contain it.
Finally, when I could take no more, I deserted our caravan.
I had a strong desire to put down roots.
I wanted to know what it was like to have a country.
I had to experience it first-hand.
It was an arduous journey,
but at last I reached the country my brother had traveled to.
I made my way to the capital where the research
facility was located, but soon lost my way.
Not a single person knew the facility's exact location.
For days I wandered the city, asking for help.
Eventually, I found a man claiming to have worked there as a researcher.
The facility was real.
He said they were studying immortality.
Such research naturally required high-quality "subjects."
My head spun.
My heart pounded as I fought the urge to vomit.
Blinded with rage, I set off in search of the facility.
The facility was deep underground.
There were rows of strange equipment.
It was eerily quiet.
I peered into one of the machines and saw machinery, cords...
and what looked like a face.
Whatever it was, it was no longer human.
Clearly these were the "subjects" of this experiment.
Then I felt this...thing lock eyes with me.
It gave me a pleading look,
and when it spoke, it sounded like a machine.
"Kill me," it said.
And then I knew.
This "thing" was my brother.
They hadn't hired us for our knowledge.
No, from the very beginning—
—they were after us.
They left my brother trapped between life and death.
So I answered his final, terrible plea.
It destroyed me.
Hope gave way to rage, and hatred burned within me.
I moved from one machine to the next
destroying them as tears streamed down my face.
That's how the guards found me,
before their bullets took my life.
I wasn't afraid. I felt no pain.
If ending those tormented lives
meant sacrificing my own,
it seemed a small price to pay.
But I can never forgive them.
The fools consumed by their quest for immortality.
"You mustn't grieve."
Those words still bind me.
They were the words my mother spoke
when my newborn sister died.
Why?
What reason do I have to deny the
feelings welling up inside me?
"You mustn't grieve."
Slowly, it dawned on me.
Those words are not for the dead.
They were made for the living.
I came to despise them.
Was hiding the pain of death from ourselves
really for the benefit of the dead?
I had to know.
Eventually the realm created the Watchers.
My parents suggested I join their ranks.
It seemed like a good idea at the time.
I'd have a chance to see the raw emotions that
grip the dead and those they leave behind.
But my time as a Watcher provided no answers.
If anything, it deepened my confusion.
Many of the souls I met had
unfinished business in the Living World.
They were utterly consumed with grief.
But those they had left behind could not grieve.
It was as though the living covered their ears
and pretended not to hear the cries of the dead.
"You mustn't grieve."
Those meaningless words became
a curse that gnawed at my very soul.
I did not grieve when my parents passed,
but not out of any desire to respect their wishes.
On the contrary, I was testing myself.
I did not overcome my sadness to bid them farewell.
I bade them farewell with no sadness at all.
I had to know what effect such a sending would
have on the dead—especially one
performed by their own flesh and blood.
I hated myself for having such thoughts.
I was a monster and a fool.
But ultimately, I was the one
who saw my parents through to the end.
They joined the ranks of the Fallen and attacked the Lost.
So I ended their misery.
Each day as a Watcher only served to dull me further.
I longed to feel sadness again.
I wanted to grieve over a passing.
The question was, "How?"
Eventually, I found the answer.
I would grieve over my own death.
After turning my back on so much misery,
I would make an exception for myself.
This would be my last testament, and my revenge.
And with that, I took my own life.
I wish I could have seen my face when it happened.
Was I in anguish, I wonder?
Sometimes I dream about myself when I was young.
I'm in a dark forest, clutching my knees and trembling.
It feels like an eternity passes.
Despair and loneliness grip me.
But I endure all of that because I'm waiting for someone.
For the kind hand I know will reach out to me.
Then I wake up, and start my day like every other.
And so it goes.
I feel nothing in my waking life.
When I left everything behind me...
...I must have left my emotions behind, too.
I can't find it in me to care about what came before.
I am an evil man now. A shadow.
And shadows need no past.
My father was the one in charge.
My siblings were a bunch of scoundrels.
Yet I can't help but wonder...
Who am I, really?
What is my true calling?
I felt as though speaking my mind would cost me everything.
So I lost myself in my work.
Taking things from people, hurting them—
I tried to make it so nothing meant anything at all.
I thought it was important I play that part.
So I could be with my family.
I only betrayed my father once.
I was young and rebellious. And impulsive.
A thin excuse, but the only one I have.
I killed without orders.
And that endangered the lives of my family.
My father nearly killed me for that.
I remember him holding me close while I glowered.
And then for some reason, I started to cry.
A realization washed over me.
I was glad this man was my father.
More than that, I was glad to be alive.
One day, I learned something terrible.
My father was being targeted by an assassin.
And an insidious one at that.
A threat to my father was a threat to my entire family.
So I decided to strike first.
No one threatens my family and lives.
Family is everything to me.
And they're the only family I've got.
The assassin arrived just as I had expected—
disguised in the garb of a traveler...
seemingly inexperienced and defenseless.
It was so convincing, I nearly hesitated to act.
But I knew what I had to do.
I was blinded by my own determination.
It was over in an instant.
When I peered at the assassin's face to make sure the deed was done—
I was met with a familiar fragrance.
The one I always smelled in my dreams.
Then I felt a coldness in my back.
My body grew numb.
As I lay prone, I thought I saw them looking down at me.
My father. My siblings.
I heard someone say, "That's the last of them."
Whatever this might have meant—
I didn't have the energy to ponder.
I only knew that I was alone again.
Filth.
That's what my father called anyone who wasn't family.
I hated my father.
My mother died giving birth to my little brother.
Father didn't even bother going to her funeral.
He cared about one thing, and one thing only:
the prosperity of our "noble" house.
My father was constantly surrounded by sycophants wearing inscrutable smiles.
I never felt more out of place than when I was with him.
I tried so desperately to appear noble on the outside.
But inside, there was another me who tried to thwart those efforts.
One who sneered at the fools I called family.
I felt as if I might be torn in half.
Yet I fought against the me that wanted to rebel.
I fought to be the ideal child my father and my family desired.
I pretended the other me didn't exist.
And I searched for the reason why I did.
My little brother was my salvation.
The only sunlight in my otherwise gloomy existence.
That was why I stayed beside him.
Not for his sake, or for anyone else's. For mine.
But those happy days didn't last long.
Soon enough we had to select the next head of the family.
It was obvious my father favored my little brother,
so of course everyone else favored him, too.
But the night of the storm changed everything.
My brother and I were with our attendants in a carriage—
when we were swept away by a landslide.
After a long search, they finally found me.
But not my brother.
The disappointment on my father's face broke my heart.
Not out of sympathy for him, but out of guilt over my own survival.
That was the only thing I felt.
I was chosen to be the head of the family.
What must I have looked like—
—surrounded by those sycophants and their inscrutable smiles?
Every day after that, I asked myself the same questions—
—over and over, in an accursed loop.
What could I have done to save my brother that night?
And why didn't I do it?
I didn't know the answer.
I had lost my conscience.
My existence has since proven valuable.
Those who, at first, mourned my brother's death
soon came to be my faithful aides.
The day my brother exchanged his life for mine
I began playing the part of the ideal family head.
Every day, they found some way to praise me.
Every day, I suffered in the shadow of my brother's ghost.
Every word I said, every action I took, was steeped in my brother's presence.
My brother had taken over my body.
Filled it with anger and hate.
I tried to fight against it at first,
but eventually I accepted my fate.
That is, until I heard the news.
My brother was alive.
Countless times, I traveled in disguise to the town where my brother was staying.
He had chosen a treacherous place
to live out his life in secret.
I relived the night of his "death" over and over.
Even if I did come face-to-face with him—
what would I say?
I didn't know, but I continued searching for him.
A plaza in shadow.
Children scrabbling for scraps.
This place stood in stark contrast to the privilege in which I lived.
Blank stares followed me everywhere, boring into my very soul.
It felt as if I were being judged.
Perhaps my brother was there watching me, too.
And if he was, what was going through his head?
The last thing I felt was excruciating pain.
I lost consciousness almost immediately.
A figure stood behind me, clutching a dully glinting blade.
I felt warmth in my belly and knew I was dying.
I wonder what this person had desired so badly—
that my life needed to be forfeit.
What did my life matter to them?
What had my brother desired of me, back then?
I don't care if he hates me... I just need to know.
I'm sorry I amounted to nothing in the end.
I'm sorry that all I ever wanted to be was myself.
I just wanted a reason to exist.
Every day dawned to battle.
The horrors of war have a way of making you forget your own exhaustion.
Somehow I managed to survive that war
without losing myself.
Mostly because I had to. For their sake.
For the sort of happiness that money can't buy.
For the only ones who made my life worth anything: my wife and daughter.
Once this horrible war was won,
there would be peace at last.
So I decided to fight.
To protect the only ones who made me happy.
That was my entire world.
The war claimed many lives, including those of my beloved wife and daughter.
Only then did I realize what a fool I'd been.
I'd snuffed the joy out of countless lives.
So it's no wonder that someone, somewhere,
ended up taking mine, too.
I had never understood that before.
I fought for my loved ones, but the war took them anyway.
What had my life been for?
Where did I fit in this world?
And what would I do now?
Eventually I stopped thinking altogether. I became an empty husk.
Far removed from the ravages of war lies a verdant land.
A land full of strangers.
It was there I began a new life.
Found a new hope.
I passed my days caring for orphans with nowhere else to go.
Protecting their futures became my only desire.
Every time one of those children remembered how to smile,
I felt as though I'd reclaimed some of my own joy.
They gave my life meaning.
They made me happy.
Again, war consumed all I held dear.
Again, only I survived.
I had nothing left.
I had nowhere to go. My life was meaningless.
I wandered the wastelands and came to the source of my suffering.
A part of me watches as I return to the battlefield.
A me that laughs.
A me that cries.
A me content to have nothing to protect,
to be ruled only by hatred.
I have nothing. I can protect nothing.
No matter how hard I fought, no matter how strong the bonds I'd formed,
I couldn't save even a single child.
I'm useless.
So why am I still here?
What was it that I believed in?
How am I supposed to protect people?
What was I supposed to do with my life?
My people were special.
That's what my father would tell me, when I was just a little girl.
"We are the chosen," he'd say with pride. "We alone can fight the Scourge."
The customs of our people seemed so normal to me then,
but they were the culmination of a thousand years of wisdom.
Sorcery.
That was our people's pride, and our purpose.
But to me, the grown-ups seemed like fools.
They quailed in fear of some fairy tale, this "Scourge."
Their lives, our history—all built around this make-believe menace.
So I scoffed at their delusions.
It seemed so obvious that they were simply cowards,
making up stories to justify their fear of the unknown.
It appeared suddenly, and without warning. Bodies soon choked the streets.
The Scourge was real,
and it had come to devour the world of man.
The defenses our people had spent a thousand years readying crumbled in an instant,
our preparations nothing more than a joke.
Our wisdom was meaningless, our pride shattered.
The great history of our people, swallowed by darkness.
I was the only survivor.
I realized that the path my people had walked was a mistake.
Pride? Wisdom? None of that mattered.
Only power had any true meaning.
That was the only defense against the Scourge.
A thousand years of civilization, and the only one who walked away was me.
Just me.
Freed though I was from history,
I set out on a new quest against the Scourge,
before it struck again.
Just as life and land slowly regenerate from devastation,
so too will that plague eventually rise again.
That's the only scrap of wisdom I salvaged from the ashes of my civilization.
And at the same time, it's the tie that binds me to my past.
I sought power. Pure and simple.
I followed trails to anything that might aid me in my quest,
and I found much.
Then, one day, I arrived at the solution: a way to manipulate reality itself!
A way to convert sheer will into pure power!
This was it! The ultimate weapon against the Scourge!
At last, it was time to move forward.
I had obtained the power and the will to destroy the Scourge, once and for all.
But there was still something I lacked.
Time.
No one lives forever, and the body is so fragile.
I have no interest in what lies Beyond the Veil.
I want to accomplish what I set out to do, while I'm still me.
So I made a decision.
I would become one with humanity's mortal foe: the shadowless.
With their power, I could warp time and extend my life.
Just as my people once bound themselves by their history,
I may have shackled myself to this meager body.
But that did not matter to me.
I fused my soul with that of the inhuman shadowless,
and gained a sort of twisted life, immortal.
I resolved to live my life on my own terms.
I was born the son of a human and a shadowless.
I'm both, and neither.
That's who I am.
Back then, that wasn't all so rare.
But unfortunately, not many of us lasted long.
Most died shortly after we were born.
For as long as I can remember, I hid who I was,
pretending to be just another human.
That's what my mother wanted.
It always struck me as odd, though.
Why did I have to hide my strength? My intelligence?
So one day, I killed my mother, and set fire to my village.
I had a dream: to live among the shadowless.
Was that so much to ask?
I was apparently more shadowless than man,
because I had no trouble fitting in among them.
My time with them was filled with surprises,
and much that sparked my imagination.
The most fascinating discovery I made, however,
was the feelings our two peoples had in common.
Humanity feared the shadowless,
and the shadowless feared humanity.
How idiotic is that?
They lived in terror of each other,
and that terror fueled their mutual hatred.
Because life is short, we seek to eliminate other life.
Knowing we shared this fear was a strangely uplifting thought.
One thing both races have in common is their obsession with survival.
I started thinking: what if all these people who feared their mortality
suddenly found themselves immortal?
What would be different?
Would anything even change?
For the first time, I felt like I had a purpose.
The search for eternal life.
Hatred? War? The end of strife?
Who cares?
There was only one thing I was interested in.
How would these two idiot races meet their end?
Thinking back to it, maybe I was the fool.
After all, it was the secrets to eternal life which I discovered
that caused the rage within both peoples
to erupt with dire consequence.
War broke out over the fruits of my research,
among humans and shadowless alike.
They fought to claim the sweet prize of eternal life.
Unexpected or not, the antics of these fools fascinated me,
and I watched with great interest as they struggled for survival.
I took a small sample of my work with me
and left the town where I resided.
On the road, I met a young boy.
He did something I found most fascinating.
Shouting that it was only to survive, he thrust a sword into my chest.
I watched the boy rifle through my pockets,
too weak now to even lift a finger to stop him.
I simply lay there, observing.
Among my belongings was the water of life itself.
The boy laid his hands on the bottle...
and tossed it carelessly aside.
He seized the trifling amount of money I had on me and fled.
I spent the remainder of my short life laughing.
How I longed to learn how civilization would meet its end.
Greed blinds us all.
Every now and then, I wonder.
Maybe long, long ago, I was human.
I feel the constant ache of impossible wounds.
I recall my past, conflicts I eagerly sought,
and a lust for battle wells up within me.
Even now I crave it.
And so, day after day,
I wander the wilds, hunting Fallen, seeking battle.
But it's never enough.
Thirsty... So thirsty...
When will my thirst be quenched? Who must I fight to quench it?
One day, I met a man.
Our eyes locked, and for a moment, both of us stood frozen.
I sensed destiny then,
a torrent of emotion rushed into my battle-parched heart!
An inferno that fed the flames of my bloodlust!
Yes... YEEES!
The man smiled at me.
"Why are you smiling?" I asked. "Is this a smile on my lips, too?"
Realization settled over me.
I had found what I had been looking for!
We fought, time and time again.
Months passed, then years. The man would not die.
Impossibly, at times I found myself on the defensive.
Me, at a disadvantage! How!?
Our battle raged on, and I wished with all my heart...
that it would last forever.
Our solitary war came to a sudden end.
The man fell in love.
He lost the will to continue our endless, bloody battle,
instead choosing to protect the ones he loved.
Why?
Our fight wasn't over.
Fight me... Fight me!
Fine! If you won't fight me, I'll kill you!
I knew I was being unreasonable, but even still.
I had once again lost my purpose, my life empty and meaningless.
This emptiness... Ah, yes.
I remember this feeling, once so familiar.
Nothing.
Would I have to suffer it again?
No. I still have hope. Him.
I can't give up yet.
I'll wait, until the day we can resume our dance of death.
Until then, I'll sleep.
And watch over the man and his kin.
That day never came.
The family he protected grew up,
matured into people who could protect him.
I see, now.
From the moment he found someone to love,
his life no longer belonged to him alone.
It was a torch that lit the fires of other souls.
That's what humans are.
Why am I me, I wonder?
Where am I going? Where should I return?
Another winter came, and again I wandered the wilds.
But with the thrill of battle lost to me, I could sense it approaching.
Death.
My end drew near. Sudden. Cruel.
My life had been pointless. I accomplished nothing.
But I regretted nothing, either.
No...there is one thing.
I don't care about the next world. I don't need a new life.
I only wish I could live among the humans.
I want someone to protect.
That was the answer I arrived at.
That's the only thing I want.
That's the only thing I need.
One of the worlds I've walked was a frozen place, a land painted in white.
Many survived by clinging to another,
their hearts closed off to the world.
The sacrifice of a young girl promised them not salvation tomorrow,
but a momentary safety today.
This I knew.
One of the worlds I've walked held memory linked to memory.
There lived a woeful people who had forgotten even the sadness of loss.
The tears of the moon,
a single drop that guarded a beautiful land of woven memories.
This I knew.
One of the worlds I've walked was one where souls were reborn.
The people questioned how to spend their fleeting lives.
It was an irrational place,
where the very things that made someone human could strip them of humanity.
This I knew.
I know much, and I know nothing.
So I exist in every world.
In the currents of time, in the vanishing folds of space.
I must know everything.
I must travel every road.
